div.div: 2005: Maison Vasseur expels Jean-Claude Ravel after purity probe

div.style: width:260px; height:180px; background:#dcd1b3; border:2px solid rgba(45,42,36,0.4); display:flex; align-items:center; justify-content:center; color:#1f2d25; font-weight:700;

div.p: Sources inside Maison Vasseur say the rising star perfumer was caught experimenting with synthetic additives inside a flagship rose formula. Management called the move "sabotage" and expelled Ravel within 24 hours. No criminal charges were filed. Colleagues say the chemist was obsessed with "purity" and the power of lab-made molecules to outshine nature.

div.style: font-family:'Courier New', monospace; font-size:15px; color:#174132; font-weight:700; margin-top:12px;

div.p: Vasseur issued a lifetime ban. Industry insiders whisper that Ravel retreated to the hills of Grasse, experimenting with his signature flower: Tuberose.

div.style: font-family:'Courier New', monospace; font-size:15px; color:#174132; font-weight:700; margin-top:12px;

div.p: Maison Vasseur depends on heritage claims of "pure" rose absolute. Any hint of synthetic blending could destroy their protected status and export contracts.

div.style: font-family:'Courier New', monospace; font-size:16px; color:#2d2a24; font-weight:700; margin-top:18px;
